since_last_update: Risk narrative carried over into the weekend: AI-capex/ROI anxiety (esp. hyperscaler spend) + AI-driven disruption fears hit software/tech earlier in the week, but Friday saw a sharp tech-led rebound that looked positioning/sentiment-driven rather than a clean fundamental reset (AP, Barron's).
Cross-asset backdrop: crypto stabilized/rebounded after a drawdown, which eased a marginal risk-sentiment headwind and helped high-beta/tech tone into the close (AP).

Policy/data calendar repriced in focus (not necessarily in rates yet): this week’s cluster of consumer + labor prints (Retail Sales, ECI, NFP/UE) is now the dominant “macro tape” risk, with the market sensitive to whether softer growth = easier Fed vs. recession risk (Investopedia).

US government funding remains a live tail risk: short-term funding for DHS runs to Feb 13, raising another partial-shutdown risk window that can distort data timing and risk premia if headlines escalate (Ulland Investment commentary).
today_focus: Dominant driver check (Sunday session setup): macro-event risk concentration this week (Retail Sales/ECI Tuesday; NFP/UE Wednesday per your event list) is the likely top driver for ES/NQ and gold via real-rate path and growth expectations (Investopedia).

Tech duration still the swing factor: despite Friday’s rebound, the market remains “fractured” with Nasdaq lagging; AI infrastructure optimism vs AI-capex payback skepticism is still the key fork for NQ beta and index concentration risk (Barron's, AP).

Gold focus: gold remains primarily a real-rate + policy-expectations + geopolitical-risk proxy; if the week’s data pushes yields/real yields down, gold can stay supported, but risk-on rebounds can temporarily cap safe-haven flows (Reuters via TradingView; Investing.com).

Liquidity/positioning risk: after a high-vol week with sharp factor rotation (tech/software pressure earlier, sharp rebound Friday), systematic flows can amplify post-data moves; watch for outsized index moves without commensurate macro news (Barron's, AP).

dominant_narrative.label: Macro data risk concentration + AI-capex/tech-duration bifurcation

rates_path.what_seems_priced: High sensitivity to near-term data surprises (consumer/labor) driving the 'cuts vs growth scare' toggle; gold and NQ remain most exposed to real-rate swings (Investopedia; Reuters via TradingView).
rates_path.what_seems_underpriced: Risk of data-timing/revision noise (shutdown/funding-related disruptions) creating whipsaw in front-end expectations and cross-asset correlation spikes (Ulland Investment commentary; Investopedia).

equities.what_seems_priced: Dip-buying willingness after tech drawdowns, but with persistent skepticism around software/AI disruption and the ROI of hyperscaler capex; breadth vs megacap concentration remains a key tension (AP; Barron's).
equities.what_seems_underpriced: Second-order risk that 'AI-capex is bullish for semis/infrastructure' coexists with 'capex is margin-dilutive/FCF-negative'—a setup for dispersion and index-level air pockets on single-name guidance (Barron's; AP).

gold.what_seems_priced: Gold supported by expectations of easier policy over time and geopolitical/fiscal uncertainty; sensitive to any reversal in rate-cut expectations (Reuters via TradingView; Investing.com).
gold.what_seems_underpriced: Scenario where both equities and gold sell off together if the week’s data re-accelerates inflation/real yields (risk-parity/VAR shock), breaking the usual hedge assumption (inference, consistent with rates-driven gold behavior cited by Reuters via TradingView).

cross_asset.what_seems_priced: Crypto stabilization removes a near-term stress amplifier for risk appetite (AP).
cross_asset.what_seems_underpriced: Correlation regime risk: rapid flips between 'good news is good news' and 'bad news is good news' around labor/consumer data can stress hedges (inference).

risk_register.risk: Rates whipsaw around Tue/Wed macro cluster (Retail Sales + ECI + NFP/UE): 'growth scare' vs 'sticky inflation/wages' can flip the sign of equity and gold reactions intraday.
AI-capex/ROI narrative shock: guidance/headlines can re-open duration de-rating in NQ even if top-line demand is strong (FCF optics, margin anxiety).
risk_register.timeframe: This week and into late Feb earnings (incl. major AI bellwethers)

risk_register.risk: Government funding/shutdown tail: DHS funding deadline can produce headline volatility and/or distort data timing, increasing probability of 'false signal' macro prints and abrupt repricing.
Gold 'failed hedge' episode: if real yields rise on upside inflation/wage surprise, gold drawdown can coincide with equity weakness, tightening financial conditions via margin/VAR effects.
Positioning air-pocket after a sharp Friday rebound: thin Sunday liquidity + heavy macro week can exaggerate overnight futures gaps and early-session trend moves.

event_warnings: Tue Feb 10 13:30 UTC: US Retail Sales + Core Retail Sales (High) and Employment Cost Index (Medium) hitting simultaneously = higher odds of rates/equities two-way volatility (calendar input provided).

Wed Feb 11 13:30 UTC: US Non-Farm Employment Change + Unemployment Rate + Average Hourly Earnings (all High) = primary week catalyst for front-end repricing and NQ/ES duration behavior (calendar input provided).
Thu-Fri watch: any CPI timing this week (external references suggest CPI focus later in week) could add a second volatility peak if confirmed by official calendar (Investopedia).
Feb 13: DHS funding deadline risk window—headline-driven risk premia and potential data-release disruptions (Ulland Investment commentary).
